intro: Malvastrum trilobum, commonly known as the three-lobed mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its hairy, rough stems and heart-shaped, three-lobed leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in disturbed areas such as roadsides and dry fields. Malvastrum trilobum is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes other flowering plants like hibiscus and cotton.
